summary: Directed by Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, collectively known as Daniels, the film is a hilarious and big-hearted sci-fi action adventure about an exhausted Chinese American woman (Michelle Yeoh) who can't seem to finish her taxes.

reviews.content: Not overwelming, but very good movie in the manner it was built.

Everything Everywhere All at Once is a simple and profound film. Using themes present in the lives of normal people, it makes many quickly identify with him. They are themes of sexual orientation, wife and husband relationship, mother and daughter relationship, company and tax and all miso mixed with fantasy, what more could we ask for? Everything Everywhere All at Once is a fun movie that makes you think about your life and the many others you could have.
Didn't enjoy the movie. It was strange and not in a good way. It didn't start out to bad but it went strange and boring fast. Really don't get why this is so positively received.
Innovative, crazy, funny, and touching. A great movie for people from 16 to 99.
Absolutely amazing. Had us laughing one moment then crying the next. Enjoyable but also makes you think. It inspired a lot of great conversation after it was finished.

I'm ashamed that I waited so long to watch this film. What a beautiful, poignant, funny, emotional movie this is. Everything from the story, the themes, the writing, the acting, and the editing makes this movie a masterpiece of cinema. The film tackles themes such as depression, nihilism, existentialism, family dynamics, and many more, with a touch of brilliant comedy sprinkled throughout. Michelle Yeoh put on a tour-de-force performance for the ages, and she deserved every award that she won. The same can be said of Ke Huy Quan. I've seen iconic movies from Citizen Kane, Vertigo, The Godfather, Goodfellas, Forrest Gump, Pulp Fiction, Schindler's List, The Shawshank Redemption, and Back to the Future. Looking back at this movie in ten years, I feel it will be given its place among those greats and regarded as such. It's a cinematic marvel and is one of the greatest movies ever made.
Ridiculous. Some short touching scenes but overall a ridiculous mess.
Watching this movie was less pleasurable than the time when a dried up dogshit was accidentally thrown into my mouth.
Wow.  So there are people that really found this entertaining?

Weird, jumping around, hard to follow. You have no idea what's going on until the very end. I can't believe I sat through the entire movie. It was like watching a tragic train wreck. Your'e not enjoying it, but keep watching to see how it ends. I do agree the acting & special effects were good, but still I felt it was just too weird.

Clever and interesting concept, my only complaints are that this movie can be a little bit confusing and disorienting, along with being a little bit too "fast paced"; it definitely lives up to its title. However, due to it being all over the place it is a bit too fast to properly understand what is going on and to get anything "down pat". But if you have the brain and the comprehension skills this movie is all the worthwhile.

The movie stoped making any sense halfway through, I don't know how this movie has any positive reviews, and I've never seen so many people walk out of a theater in the middle of a film. At one point there are two rocks talking to each other through subtitles, has everyone completely lost their mind? All these reviews must be fake.

Very enjoyable watch, the title is an accurate description for how the story feels like. Impressive effects, even more impressive story, and it's enjoyable to see both the large scale multiverse conflict mixing with the personal family conflict.
its just a weird movie. i got halfway then said thats enough. not my cup of tea. literally everyone i asked agrees. its just a very strange movie
Artistic.  Interesting.  A must see.  Not so sure on the rewatching, but for sure a must watch at least once.
Overated movie.  Winning an Oscar doesn't really seem to mean anything anymore.  Not a bad movie. Not a good movie.  Well acted.  But I couldn't wait for it to end.

I'm going to keep this short. This is the best but weirdest movies I've ever seen. On paper………should not work, but these directors, actors, cast and crew really show their genius. This is a perfect storm of talent that resulted in an oddly perfect movie.
An irritating assault on the senses with a ridiculous story. My only star is for the only funny sequence of the two rocks.

This was an over stuffed confusing movie. It's like the creators desperately wanted a martial arts film, with sci-fi and thought hot dog fingers are cool. The story lost its context and had no fluidity. It was someone's fever dream they should've kept to themselves.
Amazing in all the best and strangest ways.
An overwhelming sensory experience and overhyped, but worth it for all the cultural references you'll need to know in the future.
You can definitely see why this won so many Oscars, they ALL deserved one. Funny, endearing, unique idea, never dull for even a second.

It's absurd-just like our existence. We could be hot dog fingered people and may look like it from beyond. We could be rocks-it would be peaceful but at the expense of missing out on the beautiful chaos and connection life can bring. Whatever strange, terrible, absurd makeup of molecules we came to this world in or another world or parallel world for that matter-make your molecules send waves of positivity, connection, love. It hits different out there. 

Nothing matters, existence is absurd, yet in our own personal universes everything matters. We can't change the crazy swirling universe/s around us but we can make an impact on the the swirling universes of each person by listening to them, seeing them, treating them with kindness. That is our only hope- no one gets out of here alive.

The movie seems to take absurd to an extreme at some points but then again, does it really? Think of the absurdity of human construct. We have created a world where we dress up our natural bodies in uncomfortable clothes and spend most of our time alive inside a cubicle until almost the time of our demise for pieces of paper to buy large homes we spent in less time than we do going to the cubicle to buy them. Our existence is scientifically proven to be nothing short of miraculous and this is what we have designed to pass the time of our miraculous existence. We are absurd. Everything is. But we can be kind.

I found myself wondering when it was going to peak and it seemed to never happen. If it wasn't for the massive dildos being used as batons, it would be suitable for kids.

Prime let us watch it for free. 50 minutes in we called it quits. The narrative was pretty shoddy - clunkily half told. And if I was the Wachoeskis, is be suing for stealing the Matrix plot. Good cinematography, the odd laugh, decent cast. None of our enough to make me care, though.

Don't understand about the bad reviews and disagree about it not worth the Oscars because audiences only think the production effort shouldn't get any recognition because they didn't know with this limited budget and out of the norm storyline, this is a piece of artwork that couldn't be replicated elsewhere. The attempted storyline surprises and low budget visual effects caught my heart not because it's the best, but because it's their best from what they can offer. In fact, more than what they could offer. The story is so deep and heartfelt, for me it's not telling just about the mother-daughter relationship but a deeper understanding of a pain felt by people who lost hope in the low point of their life, it's bizarrely speaking to those who had lost their passion in living in any universe (being portrayed so painfully through the antagonist), and the "O" bagel (such a humorous element, a bagel as empty as it seem literally made me laugh in the mid of teary scenes) assuming it symbolising the emptiness in all universes is what many people face in this colourful society nowadays. And in the end the story hints about holding the very moment and seeing the beauty in all emptiness, if to be digested well, this story brings so much hope, love, in-depth view of life and some entertaining action scenes and plebeian moments that humble people can relate to. This movie is a masterpiece of bringing the theme of love without even mentioning the word "love".
loved it! great acting and awesome storyline! Michelle Yeoh is such an inspiration!

Not nearly as good as other people might lead you to believe.  It starts out incredibly slow with the story of an Asian washeteria owner, her husband, her Americanized daughter, and her wheelchair-bound, disapproving father.  At an IRS audit, her husband switches bodies with his counterpart from another universe where things are a lot more exciting and some unknown force is trying to end all other parallel universes. (SPOILER AHEAD).  He's come to convince the washeteria lady to join the fight and at first, she has no interest or belief in his antics.  Turns out, as part of switching between universes, you have to do something totally random and silly like sticking a foreign object up your backside while whistling The Star Spangled Banner.  That's not in the movie, but it's an example of how silly things can get.  Much of the movie falls back on stereotypical wire-fighting like we've seen in so many previous movies like another Michelle Yeoh vehicle, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.  If you like that sort of thing, you'll probably like this movie because it has a lot of it.  (SPOILER SPOILER SPOILER).  Turns out the force trying to end all of reality in all universes is the daughter of the washeteria owner and the rest of the movie is Michelle Yeoh's character trying to make up with her daughter and form a bond even though everyone else is telling her that, in order to save reality, she has to kill her daughter in every universe.  And so, that's it.  That's what won the Oscar.  Big disappointment for me and I'm a huge Michelle Yeoh fan.  I was even excited to see Ke Huy Quan again and he did a formidable acting job in this movie.  My biggest disappointment was the story.  Acting was fine from all involved.  While the story was somewhat original, it seems like it's just one of the pack of movies coming out lately (mainly from Marvel) where a multiverse is involved.  If imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, someone is getting mighty flattered today.
I don't get the hype

I can see why a lot of people like this. It just didn't hit for me though. It's a pretty martial arts heavy film, which I didn't know going in, and I generally don't enjoy too much. It also rest heavily on being a spectical of the surreal, which honestly it does quite well, but again, is not something I enjoy as much as the average person probably does. The acting and visual effects are well done. The story is very deep and meaningful, but for me that boggs things down way too much here. These are all smaller compaints, but the thing that cements them togther and drags down the whole experience is the runtime. At 2 hours and 20 minutes, I was just sick of it by around the 3/4 mark. I understand why people will love it, but it's not for me. 6/10

My wife, my daughter, and I tried to finish this movie a few times and finally did. We all felt the same way that we didn't get the hype over this. There are some good moments. The acting was great. Loved Jamie Lee Curtis and Shorty. They deserved their Oscars 100%. I just think the story and overall weirdness of the movie just isn't for me (us). Of course it was going to win Best Picture. It's strange, artsy-fartsy fodder that Hollywood loves. Unfortunately it doesn't have the rewatchability factor that it needs. This won't be a movie like Shawshank that ends up on TNT every Sunday. It'll likely fade into obscurity like other artistic movies like The Lighthouse.

A fantastic, powerful, silly and well thought out movie that left me thinking about how relationships work for at least a day. afterwards. Bravo!
Absolutely amazing . the story, the characters absolutely amazing.

Underwhelming. Could've won 4 Oscars (editing, costume, set design, supporting) + 2 nominations (screenplay, direction), but it's only above-average as an overall movie or experience. Not even close to the best movie of 2022 so the record-breaking number of awards is head-scratching. It's extremely derivative (the plot is The Matrix) & there are too many references to other better films throughout as it jumps from 2001 Space Odyssey reference to Matrix reference to 'some other movie' reference.

Overall it's a very silly movie, that gets stuck between two conflicting tones (melodrama & slapstick comedy). Imagine the plot of The Matrix mixed with the tone of Scott Pilgrim. It's jocular tone doesn't match it's disconsolate themes (regret & nihilism). It contains strong components, but might've been better if treated more seriously, dramatically. Allow characters, themes, & actors to create tone so your fun can be earned through story. Instead it's forcefully directed like, "let's try to make it fun." Reminds me of the quote, "there's a difference between being smart & trying to be smart." So on one hand it's a somewhat fun movie, but on the other hand its fun is a contrivance.

What worked least for me was: two rocks talking with subtitles, the personification of eternity as an everything bagel & the main character. One of the worst lead characters you'll see: completely cowardly at every turn & a nearly unbearable attempt to create an anti-hero. Thematically it's so heavy handed, it's nearly preachy. What worked best was the first few minutes of act 1 (how it was written, acted, executed). The opening character introductions, pacing & writing are excellent in a complex 'show don't tell' type manner. It quickly devolves into a slapstick time travel romp & lost it's steam once it started 'verse jumping.'

It's not a bad movie, but it wasn't a great movie like I was expecting from all of the awards and the price to rent. Nicest way I could say it is it wasn't for me. To be fair, that could be due to demographics. If you're under 30, especially female audiences, you may connect with it better. For viewers over 30, especially male audiences who's tastes might typically align with the critic scores more than audience scores, it likely will not reach your expectations & you might even find it growingly frustrating as it continually falls short of those expectations. It's best suited as a mother/daughter bonding movie with some popcorn, but it's not as universal, original, or good as it's score might have you believe.
Is an absolutely masterpiece of the nonsense and shows the true of accepting eachother and see the good we all have inside.
How on earth can this movie get such high ratings? I´ll never get it.

Just fine.  The blatant references to other films are fun at times.  Ultimately it felt drawn out and overbearing.  It's one of those films where ever piece of it was great... script, casting, acting, direction, cinematography, etc... but it's not more than the sum of it's parts. Don't understand why this film was so popular. It lagged, hurt my eyes and repeated it self, over and over and over. The only interesting character in the film was played by Ke Huy Quan.
The movie is so unique and hilarious I was compelled to make this account and leave a 5 star review.
The best movie I saw last year

First review I'm doing on Rotten Tomatoes!
I want to start of with saying that this movie is one of those movies you have to watch in one sitting and preferably on a big screen. To not have you wait for my honest feedback I'll give it now and then explain why. In all of the movies I have watched, enjoying everything from comedies to action films, sci-fi and dramas, this is absolutely the greatest masterpiece I have ever had the pleasure to watch. If I could, I would love to watch it for the first time again - such an emotional journey it takes one on.
I have to mention one thing to set your expectations straight: - do not go into this movie aching for a logical, realistic, planned through story to be told- if you do you'll be very disappointed. This is not like any other movie, this is a piece of film - the conglomerations of visuals and sound that produce tension and get the audiences attention. 
Befor watching this movie, I did not know why this movie won so many Oscar's, I was more pessimistic on the overall quality of the movie. The reason why i believe it's one of the greatest film artworks ever is because the absence of rationality and logic, of structured content and foreseeable behaviour allows the creation of feelings and a connection with the overall human emotions portrayed like no other movie has done. Because it does not make sense it feels so close to us. Most of what we experience, what we truly feel does not make sense - we can be angry but still love a person, we can have an abundance of things but still feel empty- unfulfilled. The movie creates so many different scenarios into which we can portray ourselves into, that it connects everybody to the plot ( hell I could not take my eyes off of the screen in the last 30 minutes). This gives everyone this (joy)ride of fast emotions that everyone has - the movie makes you feel happy, sad, disappointed, content, confused, orderly, scared all at the same time. The first half takes getting used to, but if you embrace the confusion, the chaos and watch the second half you'll have the absolute mesmerising experience of a wave of emotions coming over you, being captivated by the pleasure of what it feels like to be alive. Go and watch it!

I watched this movie at home after the Oscars wins. It was ambitious but they pulled it off imho. The movie started out a bit slow and confusing for me, vaguely reminding me of the Matrix, but got more interesting. The bizarre sense of humor was a welcome break from typical Hollywood tropes. I liked how the philosophical questions were posed whimsically instead of in a stereotypical pseudo-intellectual indie film way.
The cast's acting was excellent but I don't know if any of them were necessarily Oscar-worthy. Maybe it's the halo effect idk.
Like a good novel, interesting enough to be watched several times.

I was excited to see this movie , thought May be it has won the Oscar 
But it was disappointing, screenplay is so confusing that it's hard to concentrate 
There are so many loopholes
Then I tried to see from fantasy or sci fi perspective but then in 2nd half it was completely no brainer
Positive points : The idea of different universe was good , acting was also good 
Low points : Confusing screenplay , some of the people in theatre left by interval due to that , 2nd half plot was weak , illogical scenes and bad visuals. 
2/5 - bcoz of good actors and bad screenplay and confusing plots.

If I could say zero, I would.  There may be a more self-indulgent, meaningless "bucket of sh*t" (to borrow a line from the movie), but I can't think of one.  
Spoiler alert: about 2/3 through the movie, it says, "The End."  And I thought, "Thank God."
But it goes on and on and on -  I kept thinking - this is what hell is like: This movie will never end, and we can never leave.  
The Emperor's new clothes.  Has everyone lost his collective mind?
Images of Elaine reacting to "The English Patient" - "I hate it."
Bizarre and incomprehensible.
Super weird movie. Jaime lee Curtis did not deserve the Oscar, she sucks. But the movie was so weird and I don't know why the ratings are so high
Much too much to take in.

An excellent film. The best film to come out in 2022 from what I've seen. The divide between people liking and hating this film is quite intriguing. The majority of audience members who gave very low stars seemed to have stopped watching before the halfway point. I'd recommend giving the movie another chance and watching all the way through but i can understand why this movie is not for everyone everywhere all the time. I did enjoy it both as a regular person and a fan of cinema, the cinemaniac in me especially liked it. I can see why it won so many Oscars. It seems to appeal more to the critic than the average moviegoer. It is still a modern masterpiece.

Even though I got into the cinema 30 minutes late, the rest of the 100 minutes were mind-blowing! Never thought anyone would be brave enough to make a movie about the parallel worlds and make it a blockbuster, not to mention the numerous awards that it has been receiving around the world. It's funny, serious, deep and heartwarming all in one movie. It can't get anymore entertaining that this.  It is a success for very good reasons! I'm genuinely happy that all aspects of the production have been appreciated.

We all agreed with the following- 
Unique- yes.
Bonkers - yes.
Long- very.
Boring - definitely. 
I really don't know what all the fuss is about. 
Glad it was (finally) over.
 Oh yes - I did like the soundtrack by Son Lux.
Oof, that WAS Rotten! And this won all of the awards? I really wanted to like this movie but  finally turned it off a little over half way through.

I was definitely more interested in the first half where it was a weird mixture of sci fi mixed with well choreographed fight scenes. But then the second half comes along and basically throws all that out the window. It does some neat things with the camera work and aspect ratio, but that’s about it outside the fight scenes. A little too preachy by the end just had me rolling my eyes more than anything.

Outstanding acting, super inventive scenario, all for a very refreshing movie experience.

A24, a production company always willing to gamble on original ideas, outdo themselves with Everything Everywhere All at Once, an all-out assault on the senses that never fails to entertain.  Evelyn (Michelle Yeoh), a mother who comes to the realization that she is becoming estranged from her daughter (Stephanie Hsu), finds herself drawn into alternate universes and the fulcrum in a galactic battle for supremacy.  It's a wildly psychedelic, existential journey that includes googly eyes, a pair of telepathic rocks, and a talking racoon, among other oddities, all of which sounds ridiculous but somehow works in the context of the film.  More importantly, despite all of the weirdness, it is a movie that has heart. It's clearly not for all tastes, but those with patience will probably find it rewarding.

Sci-fi action-comedy masterpiece!

"Everything Everywhere All at Once" is an extraordinary film that defies categorization. Directed by Dan Kwan and Daniel Scheinert, this sci-fi action-comedy features an outstanding cast led by Michelle Yeoh, Jamie Lee Curtis, and Stephanie Hsu. The film tells the story of a woman named Mei, played by Hsu, who discovers she has access to multiple parallel universes and must navigate them to save her world from destruction.

One of the most impressive aspects of the film is its visual style. The directors utilize an array of cinematic techniques, including animation, puppetry, and practical effects, to create a unique and mesmerizing visual experience. The cinematography is stunning, with vibrant colors and dynamic camera movements that keep the audience engaged throughout the film.

The performances are also outstanding, with each actor bringing a unique energy and charisma to their role. Yeoh delivers a powerful performance as the enigmatic Madame Wong, while Curtis is hilarious as a ruthless businesswoman who becomes embroiled in the chaos of Mei's mission.

But perhaps the most impressive aspect of "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is its storytelling. The film manages to balance multiple genres, including science fiction, action, comedy, and drama, with remarkable ease. The narrative is complex and engaging, and the filmmakers masterfully weave together the different threads of the story to create a satisfying and emotional conclusion.

Overall, "Everything Everywhere All at Once" is a remarkable piece of cinema that is sure to become a classic. With its stunning visuals, outstanding performances, and compelling storytelling, it stands out as one of the best films of all time. It's a must-see for anyone who appreciates bold, innovative filmmaking and a testament to the boundless potential of cinema as an art form.

Rarely does a title of a film exemplify both the on the screen action as well as the theme of the movie.  Everything, Everywhere, All at Once, certainly does.  What is going on during this movie?  Well…Everything…Where?  Everywhere…When…OK..  
Touching on themes of existentialism, nihilism and family, Everything reminds audiences to soak in the little things in life even in the face of modernity, cynicism, and the increasing feeling that we are getting smaller and smaller in a world of constant technological advancement.

That this film won the Oscar for Best Movie indicates the Academy is fascinated by style over substance. There's a message in this movie and it beats you over the head, in the face, on your backside...and covers up the redundancy with a bunch of nonsense about the multiverse. Whatever.

You're not supposed to say the quiet part loud but I'm going to: this won at the Oscars for one reason and one reason only, DEI. It's an average film at best that won due to weak competition or films that were overlooked that should have easily won but were snubbed for Best Picture and Best Director (and yes, I'm talking about THE WHALE and Darren Aronofsky). Within a year this film will be forgotten. Don't get me wrong, I'm extremely happy Laurie Strode won an Oscar (surprised in fact as the buzz heading in was Angela Bassett would win), as well as Ke Huy Quen who will always have a special place in my heart like so many others for Data and Short Round. Finally, isn't it cultural appropriation for Daniel Scheinert to direct basically an all Asian cast? Just asking.

This film was literally unwatchable for me. 

I got headaches from the audiovisual experience, but also from constantly rolling my eyes.

I almost never give up on a film, so I soldiered through this torturous assault on the senses, taking breaks every 30 minutes or so.

From the first minute, it starts out with people frantically rushing, tripping and talking over each other seemingly in fast-forward, constantly switching between English and Cantonese. First you think that this is intentional, so as to convey the chaotic situation, and once it is established, the pace and tone will settle down. Nope. This is the entire film. 

The film is a nonsensical mish-mash cacophony of frantic, hectic, hyper, non-stop dialog, noise, lights, people, and things. I understand that this is the point, and it's supposed to be Funny & Satirical & Smart & Weird & Sweet & Edgy & Silly & Serious & Meta.

However in my opinion it tries way, way too hard, and ultimately falls flat on its face in all its aspirations. At least the title is apt.

Surprise-Surprise, trying to be Everything Everywhere, all at once... doesn't work! At least not for me, as I see that it does for many others. (I will leave the audience cultural psychoanalysis to others 🤪)

The film is simultaneously sensory overwhelming, and very boring. Dumb, but pretentious at the same time. Both branching & multi-verse hoping, but also repetitive and so very predictable. Quite the accomplishment.

Stephanie Hsu and Jamie Lee Curtis fill their respective roles with candor, Curtis with bracing comedy and Hsu with love towards her parents in the film, Yeoh and Quan. The Daniels, above all, are incredibly hilarious with their independent style of filmmaking, nothing is definable and everything is original, thoroughly earning their incredibly moving film's ambitious title.

Easily the best movie I've seen in the last 10 years. The Daniels as writers/directors are clearly lovers of this craft and not only paid homage to the films that influenced them, but pushed the art of the film medium to new heights. If you understand the concept on suspension of disbelief, you will be deeply moved by this film. On a side note, Stephanie Hsu was robbed of the Academy award for Best Supporting Actress in this movie with her incredible depth and range to her character.
This will become one of those films that you rewatch every year. A modern classic.

The multiverse theory is just a mathematical way to explain the way a universe that favors life could come about randomly and is actually a way to show a way to satisfy the Cosmological Constant and the infinitesimal chance that life could have come about:  Parallel universes containing other versions of ourselves is not a part of the theory.  The only 5 minutes of the movie I liked was the part with the two rocks in the cliff with total silence.

This is a Once in a generation type film. The single most original, unique, technically advanced perfect example of filmmaking and entertainment that I have witnessed since the early 90s. Plot was very easy to follow along despite what some low ratings say. Like all the films by the masters with names like Martin Scorcese, Sergio Leone, Stanley Kubrick, Steven Spielberg and Alfred Hitchcock, you simply have to pay attention to the screen. I would rank this one right up there with any films the great masters ever made. It's not for the people who love "Cocaine Bear" or franchise sequels Like marvel movies. It's made for people who love cinema.  It's a Comedy /sci-fi / action film based around a story of a struggling immigrant family on the verge of divorce and their daughter's nihilist attitudes. If you can watch this movie and not laugh and cry at least once, you need to check your pulse, cause you might be dead. 
It's easily going somewhere in my top 10 list of favorite films of all time... Right up there with "2001 a Space Odyssey", "Once Upon a Time in New York",  and "Goodfellas"... oh yea...

I get it. I understand about the ricocheting consequences of choices made early in our lives.  I understand not being able to cope with the fact that every choice is a trade-off of good and bad. I understand reconciling a mundane life in valid existence of family and loved ones. I even understand the rest of the banal universal themes. But why do I have to go through torture to hear someone make these points? Afull third of the movie is fake kung fu fighting with unrealistic consequences. I'm sure there's lots of 13 year-old boys who love this stuff. But why put sentient adults through this?

It starts with a family mirror.
...and then we see an agitated Evelyn, a broken mirror, a multiverse of different fragments of herself.
An App gives Evelyn access to skilful versions of herself to deal with a disturbance in her fragmented world, and still, Evelyn decides to remain an unskilled, but better-resolved, loving mother.
We all left some goals or better versions of ourselves behind, and in a certain way, all the goals can be seen as futile achievements compared with the infinitude of outer space.
In the end, Evelyn is less frantic, all at once, enjoying the small miracles.
Mitski & David Byrne offer the final balm - "This is a Life".

I've read so much about "Everything Everywhere All at Once" as a sci-fi movie--and I'm a sci-fi lover, so I had to see it. But what really stands out for me is the film's humanity. Hats off to Michelle Yeoh for her complex portrayal of Evelyn and kick-butt action sequences. Ke Huy Quan gives a delightful and surprising performance as her husband. I really loved this movie.

I just came here to say that this was an interesting movie and it deserves credit for it's uniqueness but I'm not seeing why it cleaned up at the Oscars. Furthermore, it is absolutely blasphemous that Jamie Lee Curtis could win best supporting actress over Angela Bassett. Yes, Jamie Lee Curtis's role was very diverse in Everything Everywhere All At Once, but it certainly did not deserve recognition over Angela bassett's performance and Wakanda Forever. More credit should have been done to the costume and makeup team for Jamie Lee Curtis's character. It was not emotional, it was not groundbreaking, it was not moving, and you would barely know she was in it because it was such an insignificant role as far as impact is concerned. On the other hand, Angela bassett's performance was emotional, it was heartfelt, it was strong, it was passionate, it was memorable, and she was absolutely snubbed. The academy should be ashamed of themselves because this choice seemed more of a racially biased move or political move, I can't put my finger on it but they definitely got that one wrong and missed an opportunity to give a premiere actress her flowers while she's still with us. I noticed that there's been criticism of the movie Wakanda Forever as there are many people in the United States, and across the world, that have a hard time grasping the idea of an elite African nation, on top of the food chain that, couple with the fact that the movie highlights some injustices on behalf of the white man. I get it, but let's take off our blinders and be real. Conversely, EEAAO is receiving positivity biased kudos due to the industry's recent infatuation with Asian inclusivity. And don't get me wrong, the actors in this movie are absolutely phenomenal and this is nothing against them, this is against the academy, this is against the biased critics. Yes, the movie is different and refreshing but that does not make it a better movie than some of its competing films.

I think the acting was phenomenal, and that the general storyline held a lot of promise and significance.  I believe they chose a heroine and a storyline in general which provided a lot of social commentary about modern American life, and the overwhelming nature of our capitalist culture and how it punishes minorities the most.  

Unfortunately, the film seems to lack an articulated or properly-maintained plot at points, and tries to juggle way too many different themes and directions at the same time to be comprehensible.  I was very frustrated by how often the plot took off ramps onto another theme or action scene, without fully developing and explaining what was going on (descriptively or symbolically) in the previous scenes.  I'm guessing this may have something to do with the average American's ever decreasing attention span and critical thinking skills, which seems to have negatively influenced Hollywood film directing over the years.  Regardless of the real reason behind these directing decisions, it made it very difficult to absorb the material at times.

I was also disappointed with the character development of Jobu Tupaki/Joy.  I never felt the audience got sufficient explanation or context behind /why/ she was so suicidal and hostile toward her mother, beyond some superficial information detailing typical parent/ teen child antagonism, or the story of split personalities due to too much multiverse switching.  Someone who is going through complex suffering and struggles to develop into that character deserves a comprehensive backstory and contextual interpretation.  Perhaps some of the explanations for her pain lie in inter-generational conflicts within Chinese American families, in which case that explanation may have been lost in cultural translation.  But I also think aspects of her backstory and character may have also just been poorly written.

Also, there are far too many kink and BDSM material to make me feel comfortable. Unless these BDSM scenes were poorly-developed attempts at satire, the film seemed to otherwise be promoting a culture that for many people is often one of out-of-control consumerism, exploitation, and abuse.  I get it, adding this material gives the illusion of adding prestige, exoticism, or 'intricacy' to a film.  That's often the effect BDSM references have on general audiences, since that culture is taken at face value as a 'rebellion against normalcy'.  Introducing BDSM themes out of context also has some kind of shock and awe effect, and can be injected in content that may not otherwise be sufficiently thought provoking.  But that's just it, the real value of this material is illusive, and putting motifs of kinky practices in film to substitute more powerful messages or ideas can't fool everyone.  That's not including how gross and disturbing a lot of the kink content was to begin with.

An incredible film blending genres and cultures into an enjoyable and heart-felt experience. EEAAO perfectly captures the struggles of most first-gen Asian-American families. The heavy expectations set on the son or daughter, the constant need for success while ignoring the people surrounding them, and the perpetual financial struggles. However, this film speaks not only to the Asian diaspora but for everyone. Sometimes we question why do this or that, and we spiral into some sort of nihilistic view of the world. Not every choice has to be perfect or meaningful leading to a cascade of successes. In the end, the millions of possibilities you denied for one that you thought mattered, that's pretty beautiful and significant.

"Everything Everywhere All At Once" is an outstanding movie that takes the audience on a mesmerizing journey through multiple dimensions, blurring the lines between reality and fantasy. The film showcases a brilliant and diverse cast, who all deliver powerful performances that leave a lasting impact on the audience.

The film's visual effects are stunning, seamlessly blending the real world with the imaginary realms, and immersing the viewer in a unique and captivating cinematic experience. The storyline is intricate yet accessible, weaving together multiple themes such as love, loss, and self-discovery, that are universally relatable and emotionally resonant.

The film's score is equally impressive, with a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack that adds an extra layer of depth and emotion to each scene. The direction and cinematography are also top-notch, masterfully capturing the film's complex narrative in a visually stunning and cohesive way.

Overall, "Everything Everywhere All At Once" is a must-see movie that is sure to delight audiences of all ages and backgrounds. Its rich characters, stunning visuals, and powerful storytelling are a true testament to the talent and creativity of its filmmakers. It is no surprise that the film has won all the Oscars, and it is a well-deserved honor.

An absolutely crazy brilliant MASTERPIECE! Every once in awhile you stumble across something that just… fades everything else around you away… and you stare transfixed, knowing at that moment you are watching something truly special. 

NOTE: This movie is not for everyone. It definitely isn't an ordinary movie. It is more of an indy that focuses on pushing the creative envelope and dares to be strange, if not straight-up absurd at times. Personally, I love movies that are unusual. So this… was right up my alley. 

It was dramatic, confusing, funny as all hell, deeply philosophical, action packed, surrealist, eye-popping, pure wtf crazy, that literally had me laughing my ass off at one moment and then crying like a big baby man later. 

If I had to sum this movie up… in just one word… it would be "beautiful". 

We are all such a mess dealing with a world that is such a mess, but being a mess is… "beautiful". 

Probably one of the most poignant movies I've ever seen. And it had people with hot dog fingers, a guy with a raccoon on his head, fight scenes using butt plugs, and long long silent scenes with rocks with googly eyes that moved me to tears. 

A true piece of art that just got me. 

2 huge hot dog thumbs up!

I hope this opens up opportunities for film makers to be able to delve more confidently into the "weird but wonderful" genre.

This movie seems to be like marmite with the audience - so many 5 star reviews followed by 1 star reviews. For me, it's a masterpiece and it quickly became my favourite movie of all time! I don't like the fact that everything nowadays is either a sequel/prequel/remake. It's like people are running out of ideas! But not with this movie - it was the most unique movie I can remember watching. It had everything: humour, sci-fi, action, martial arts and so much raw emotion. The emotion was so strong that I cried one minute and was belly laughing the next. At one point I didn't know if my tears were from laughing or feeling emotional. All thanks to the incredible acting and brilliant script! It must be so difficult for the actors to do comedy acting one minute and then pour so much emotion into the role the next, not to mention all of the action scenes. I appreciate some won't get it, for me and my easily bored ADHD brain it was absolutely perfect! I wonder if the ones that walked out did so when the movie pretended to end! I've watched it three times and could watch it many more. You always see something different the next time you see it. I'm so glad something so unique has won so many awards, and I was rooting for them all during the whole awards season and so happy with the Oscars wins. Although I would say Stephanie Hsu should have got best supporting actress at the Oscar's over Jamie Lee (even though she was excellent too). I hope there's more unique movies like this in the future rather than another remake!!

At the end of the day it's a glorified "Mom doesn't understand her family and wants a better life" movie. The storyline with the husband was good, the acting was amazing, but it was pretty easy to see from the beginning that we were working towards acceptance of the daughter's partner. Also the rock metaphor didn't track cause she lets her fall off the cliff and then  when she's convincing her to stay she falls off the cliff after her? Didn't really make sense. At the end of the day though this movie's composition rings true to its' message: Nothing really matters. Yeah thanks that's what I needed 😂

I saw this movie shortly after it first came out, not knowing much at all about it and absolutely loved it.  Partly, at its core it is a story about an immigrant family and their relationships and as the daughter of an immigrant mother a lot of the issues beneath all the crazy multiverse scenes were familiar and heartfelt.  Partly it is about nihilism vs love/kindness/connection which for me was another relatable piece.  And partly I was impressed at the overall creativity, acting and humor.  It was not like most films nowadays that are all focused on action or gratuitous violence or predictable tropes.  Yes, the pace was a bit manic at first and took me a bit to fully get where they were heading but I left the theater deeply moved.  I saw it a second time recently, now knowing the plot (and the hype) and it didn't land quite as strongly, but I noticed a lot more fun bits that I missed the first time and I remain impressed at the creativity and basic heart/feeling the film has.

This masterpiece is all about everything happening everywhere, just like the title. And I assure you that you will feel the same way as I do when you watch it. So there will be a question about what is even "everything" to start with. Everything is about your life and those people who you are surrounded with. This movie may be fictional by the inclusion of a multiverse but the depiction of underlying philosophical meaning about the realistic view of family issues, life choices, and all the possibilities we could create from small insignificant decisions in our daily lives reflect and wonder about our lives a lot. The whole plot itself takes place in the multiverse which might be something confusing when people who are unfamiliar with the concept hear that but surprisingly it is very simple to comprehend the whole plot. 

It will give you a tremendous amount of different emotions, some of them which you might not have even experienced before. At least, it was that way for me. Many types of comedy also take place in the plot frequently and all of them are fantastic and in perfect timing. Despite having so many funny and ridiculous scenes, the plot itself is very serious to the point everyone can relate to either characters or situations in their lives such as the scenes when the movie depicted the young couple making "wrong" choices in this universe, the parenthood focusing on both the perspective of the wife (Evelyn)  and the husband (Waymond), their teenage daughter (Joy)'s problems concerning her life choices being unaccepted by her mother, ruined and shattered hopes from a young couple,  their business situations, the typical dead romance between the long-married couple (especially Asian couples), and many other characters' plots and viewpoints.


There are no villains in this movie. At the first glance, you might probably think (as it is stereotyped) of the mysterious character who seems to have bad intentions toward the universe, Jobu Tupaki (Joy) as the villainess. But if you can truly apprehend the way she becomes who she is, her actions are not justifiable but are understandable. Then, her mother would be the one you would want to blame for making Joy the way she is. But turns out, that is also not the case as everyone always wants the best for themselves or their loved ones. Her mother's action is also understandable but not justifiable. So in short, either her father, her grandfather and his organization, her mother, herself and everyone and every version of them in different universes cannot be blamed as it is going in a circle, and not one person can be blamed for one exact cause. 

Last of all, "Nothing matters", the main concept of this movie. This line mentioned by Jobu Tupaki(Joy) is a very simple yet powerful line for everyone everywhere it also shows her belief in one of the most famous philosophical branches called Nihilism. She tried to end the whole multiverse and universes by sucking everything into the giant bagel with her superpowers because nothing really matters to her anymore. But the fact that she wanted to end it together with her mother from the far multiverse shows that someone still matters to her and if we think carefully about Joy, she is doing all these things because of the concept of "nothing matters" matters to her. And yes it actually feels nice to think that way because if nothing matters, all the pain and guilt we feel from nothing of our lives go away as it is stated by Jobu Tupaki. But on the contrary and concluding from the ending and Evelyn's fighting scene against her daughter to stop her from going into the bagel, we can say that because nothing really matters, it is our choice to decide what and who matters in our daily lives and give and try our best for them no matter whatever the hardship we may face. I think that everyone should watch this movie at least once in their lifetime. You will get an unbelievably amazing experience and feeling in the duration of these 2 hours.

I'm going to be blunt: This movie is like a bright speckled donut injected with some super stale bland bread and with a hollow core.

We get it. It's a story about a mother of a depressed, anxious suicidal young adult, but the treatment is so shallow that if you try to dive in you'll break something. 

Daughter: The writers never really get into the daughter and present her as a flapping conundrum for the mother. The writers see fit to laminate a layer of gay in the daughter as if somehow that helps support the daughter's feelings (offensive meter is ticking), but never really delve into the experience of being gay and they never show a moment of gayness in the film, they just slap a label on her, make her hold a girl's hand and the job is done. Instead they focus on presenting the daughter as a writhing ball of whimsical existential angst - and that's it.

On to the mother: Just a trope of a character. Maternal angst meets bored middle aged woman stuck in a rut. Yay.

Their relationship: They don't have one. It's just two shallow characters, one pulling away and the other trying to cling on, "SAVE" the other from themselves and neither really understanding the other. Hot tip for the writers: without you guys writing these characters as more than a window shop painting, you can't write true connection between them. How do you display human understanding between two characters if there's nothing for the audience to understand either?

The rest of the movie was shiny and silly. 

The shine: The shine was pretty. Lots of pretty things. They were shiny. They were well done. I liked them! But you can't watch 2:20 of shiny things alone… well I cant. Gummies aren't legal where I live.

The silly: The kind of silly people who wear Depends appreciate, but for everyone else it's like trying to share a meal with the same person after they've taken their evening Xanax.

A smart, funny, action packed, and simultaneously sincere film that is incredibly fresh. While definitely a strange concept, it uses the multiverse setup to discuss difficult concepts such as nihilism with an incredibly honest and well thought touch while maintaining its wacky antics. It is most certainly a bit of a niche film, but I would suggest everyone to at least give this film a chance because there is something really special hidden behind all the crazy martial arts and multiverse shenanigans.

Great acting from all involved especially Michelle Yeah (Evelyn), Ke Huy Quan (Waymond), Jamie Lee Curtis (Deirdre) and Stephanie Hsu (Joy), the first three of which won oscars for their performance at the 95th academy awards. despite the complex storyline the film is easy to follow and understandable. This credits the co-directors, Daniel Kwan and Daniel Scheinert ("the Daniels"), winning the academy award for best screenplay and best director. The film was nominated for 11 oscars going into the ceremony and came out with 7 of them, including best actress in a leading role (Michelle Yeah), best actress in a supporting role (Jamie Lee Curtis), best actor in supporting role (Ke Huy Quan), directing (The Daniels) and best picture.
